prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: band6_cloudb
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of cloud B. 27 pointings. Band 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our science goals require both excellent continuum sensitivity and spectrally resolved molecular line observations. To maximise continuum sensitivity we choose 4 spectral windows with a uniform bandwidth of 1875 MHz. In order to minimise the data rate (see below), while resolving line profiles of 3-4 km/s, we request a channel spacing of 1129MHz (~1.4 km/s).
We have manually centred the 4 spectral windows at 253.5, 255.5, 268.3, and 271.1GHz. This frequency setup covers many lines with a wide range of excitation conditions, including dense (HCO+, HNC) and shocked gas tracers (SO2, CH3OH, 13CH3OH), as well optically thin lines (HC18O+, 15NNH+). Line widths within the CMZ are typically very broad. Our ALMA cycle 0 observations of G0.253+0.016 reveal line widths ~20 km/s, but some can be as low as 3-4 km/s. Thus we can still resolve these lines with ~1.4 km/s resolution whilst also minimising the data rate (see below). Whilst line widths of ~<1 km/s have been reported in G0.253+0.016 in high-critical density gas tracers (Kauffmann et al. 2013), mean line widths are of the order 14 km/s (velocity dispersions of ~ 6kms/s) in accordance with those measured by Rathborne et al. 2015 in Cycle 0 ALMA data at 3mm.
This frequency setup incorporating both continuum and molecular line data will enable us to achieve our primary science goals of establishing robust core mass functions (requires both continuum and lines) and column density probability distribution functions for each of the sources. Additionally, the range of molecular lines selected will provide a detailed understanding of the gas kinematics within these clouds, allowing us to determine: (i) large-scale velocity gradients across the clouds and (ii) accurate velocity dispersions (iii) the relative velocity of high-density cores.

We require a spatial resolution of 0.04pc to resolve both dense cores and their separation. This corresponds to an angular resolution of 1'' at the distance of the CMZ (8.4 kpc; Reid et al., 2014), and is sufficient to resolve the density peaks in the hydrodynamical simulations (kruijssen et al. in prep.).
To develop a robust cdPDF, it is required that we mosaic the entire cloud. With recommended sampling, at ~260GHz, Cloud B can be imaged with a rectangular mosaic of 27 pointings. This will provide sufficient independent pixels (low enough Poisson noise per bin) to differentiate between cdPDFs of the different clouds.
Additionally, it is important that we recover the large spatial scale emission. Since the largest recoverable scale is ~ 10'' with the 12m array (corresponding to 0.4 pc), complimentary ACA observations are required. ACA-TP observations are also required to complement the line observations and probe scales over 18'' (0.75 pc; cloud radii are ~ a few pc).

We request a continuum sensitivity of 0.09 mJy/beam over a 6 GHz bandwidth. Cycle 0 and cycle 1 observations of G0.253+0.016 (Rathborne 2014b; 2015) show that there are many bright molecular lines within broad (1.875 GHz) spectral windows. We estimate a conservative 20% contamination due to molecular lines (hence 6GHz of bandwidth for the time estimate). Note that the achieved RMS over the total 7.5 GHz bandwidth is 0.08 mJy/beam.
The continuum sensitivity of 0.09 mJy/beam is that required for a 5 sigma column density detection of ~ 10^22 cm^-2. This value has been determined from previous Cycle 0 observations of G0.253+0.016 (Rathborne et al., 2014b) and synthetic observations of hydrodynamical simulations of clouds in orbit around the Galactic centre (Kruijssen et al., in prep.). This value ensures that the four key components of the column density probability distribution function (the dispersion; peak; x_crit [see Section 3 of science case]; and the power law tail) are recovered in all prospective clouds, and allows us to look for variation from cloud-to-cloud. This column density sensitivity is dependent on the assumed dust properties. Here we have assumed a dust temperature (20 K; Molinari et al. 2011). A higher temperature would result in greater column density sensitivity which would further aid our observations.
Additionally, this continuum sensitivity provides a 5 sigma mass sensitivity of 0.4 solar masses (assuming the same dust properties as above). Cycle 0 and Cycle 1 observations recover the core mass function down to ~ a few solar masses. Therefore, we will also be able to test for any changes in the power law slope of the CMF derived for individual clouds, and to make comparison between CMFs derived for the dust ridge clouds.
Typical line widths within the CMZ are greater than those observed within the disc for the same size scale on average (~3-20 km/s at the size scales probed with the proposed spatial resolution; Rathborne et al., 2015, Shetty et al. 2012). We therefore request a uniform spectral resolution of 1.129 MHz across all spectral windows. This enables the simultaneous detection of molecular lines in our continuum bands (1.4 km/s resolution). We have placed our spectral windows to specifically target a number of molecular lines, namely: HCO+ (3-2), HC18O+ (3-2), HNC (3-2), CH3OH, 13CH3OH, SO2, HCS+, H2CS, 15NNH+, NHD2. Although the bandwidth used for the continuum flux sensitivity is much wider than the lines of interest, the estimated time per pointing for each science goal is ~ 60s, providing ~ 7mJy/beam sensitivity (equivalent to ~ 0.14 K) per ~ 1.4 km/s channel.
We have used non-LTE radiative transfer code, RADEX, to estimate line strengths of the molecular species within our setup (where possible). We have assumed a line width of 3 km/s and a temperature of 20 K, and have taken two extremes: a low-mass core of 0.5 Msun, and a high-mass core of 10 Msun (estimating their volume densities and the column density of the relevant tracer assuming typical abundance ratios). This represents a lower limit to the gas temperature where we have made the assumption that the gas temperature = dust temperature (Clark et al 2012) within the dense molecular clouds (increasing the gas temperature to 50K leads to greater line intensities in RADEX).
For the lower mass cores RADEX predicts significant line intensities (> 5 sigma) for the abundant dense gas tracers HCO+ and HNC. In the higher mass regime, abundant tracers become optically thick. Here, emission from higher critical density molecules such as HC18O+, SO2, HCS and H2CS will be significant (>5 sigma), and remain optically thin (good tracers of the gas kinematics). Thus, with a line sensitivity of ~0.14K at a resolution of 1.4km/s, we expect to attain good detections of the line emission for all mass regimes.

We have actively sought to decrease the data rate by using spectral averaging by a factor of 2 in all of our bands. We note that our data rate of 12.21 MB/s is slightly above the 12 MB/s recommended limit. As discussed above, as we are coving a range of molecules tracing different excitation conditions we require the broadest 1875 MHz bandwidth with uniform resolution of ~1.4 km/s in order to cover all lines and resolve the narrowest (3-4 km/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: band6_cloude
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of cloud E. 77 pointings. Band 6.

Additionally, this continuum sensitivity provides a 5 sigma mass sensitivity of 0.4 solar masses (assuming the same dust properties as above). Cycle 0 and Cycle 1 observations recover the core mass function down to ~ a few solar masses. Therefore, we will also be able to test for any changes in the power law slope of the CMF derived for individual clouds, and to make comparison between CMFs derived for the dust ridge clouds.
Typical line widths within the CMZ are greater than those observed within the disc for the same size scale on average (~3-20 km/s at the size scales probed with the proposed spatial resolution; Rathborne et al., 2015, Shetty et al. 2012). We therefore request a uniform spectral resolution of 1.129 MHz across all spectral windows. This enables the simultaneous detection of molecular lines in our continuum bands (1.4 km/s resolution). We have placed our spectral windows to specifically target a number of molecular lines, namely: HCO+ (3-2), HC18O+ (3-2), HNC (3-2), CH3OH, 13CH3OH, SO2, HCS+, H2CS, 15NNH+, NHD2. Although the bandwidth used for the continuum flux sensitivity is much wider than the lines of interest, the estimated time per pointing for each science goal is ~ 60s, providing ~ 7mJy/beam sensitivity (equivalent to ~ 0.14 K) per ~ 1.4 km/s channel.
We have used non-LTE radiative transfer code, RADEX, to estimate line strengths of the molecular species within our setup (where possible). We have assumed a line width of 3 km/s and a temperature of 20 K, and have taken two extremes: a low-mass core of 0.5 Msun, and a high-mass core of 10 Msun (estimating their volume densities and the column density of the relevant tracer assuming typical abundance ratios). This represents a lower limit to the gas temperature where we have made the assumption that the gas temperature = dust temperature (Clark et al 2012) within the dense molecular clouds (increasing the gas temperature to 50K leads to greater line intensities in RADEX).
For the lower mass cores RADEX predicts significant line intensities (> 5 sigma) for the abundant dense gas tracers HCO+ and HNC. In the higher mass regime, abundant tracers become optically thick. Here, emission from higher critical density molecules such as HC18O+, SO2, HCS and H2CS will be significant (>5 sigma), and remain optically thin (good tracers of the gas kinematics). Thus, with a line sensitivity of ~0.14K at a resolution of 1.4km/s, we expect to attain good detections of the line emission for all mass regimes.

We have actively sought to decrease the data rate by using spectral averaging by a factor of 2 in all of our bands. We note that our data rate of 12.21 MB/s is slightly above the 12 MB/s recommended limit. As discussed above, as we are coving a range of molecules tracing different excitation conditions we require the broadest 1875 MHz bandwidth with uniform resolution of ~1.4 km/s in order to cover all lines and resolve the narrowest (3-4 km/s).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The ultimate goal of star formation (SF) studies is an end-to-end understanding of stellar mass assembly as a function of environment. This proposal aims to study a unique system of clouds in the extreme environment of the Galactic centre. Our principle goals are: 1. Investigating the role of environment in SF - directly testing theoretical predictions of molecular cloud structure in high-pressure environments - unambiguously determining whether "universal" SF relations differ in this cosmologically important regime; 2. Following the evolution of SF in five of the most massive molecular clouds within the Galaxy - testing the hypothesis that SF within GC clouds may be causally-related, triggered by close passage to the bottom of the Galactic gravitational potential. If confirmed, this will provide a truly unique opportunity to study stellar mass assembly as a function of absolute time, opening up a new and exciting frontier in SF research.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: A similar proposal was submitted in Cycle 2 and ranked category C - 2013.1.00617.S. Our Cycle 3 submission however, incorporates a new spectral setup, and a greater spatial coverage based on new theoretical/simulation developments and our experience from Cycle 0 and 1 data. It therefore does not represent a direct resubmission, and we request that if accepted the observations are carried out in Cycle 3 even in the unlikely event that the Cycle 2 observations are completed.
